setup.question: Why does Koroby feel motivated to start the fire?
answers: She has had her heart broken and is fueled by rage
She does not wish to marry Yasak, so must create a diversion

Text.text: Koroby is an alien who lives on Venus. One day, a man from Earth named Robert crash lands on Venus in his spaceship. Koroby is infatuated with him and later when they get back to the city, she confesses to Robert:
; but he reacts apathetically and doesn't reciprocate the feelings. Koroby is pissed, and reacts harshly,
. Then, while Robert is leaving,
, setting fire to the ground until the flames reached Robert,
, finally killing him.
The story follows Koroby, a Venusian woman who is set to marry Yasak. Just from the beginning she is unsure of whether she wants to marry Koroby.
This is because she wants to meet the actual love of her life, who turns out to be Robert.
. Robert intimidates Yasak, and he feels threatened by Robert's presence:
Koroby starts a fire to allow for Robert to escape, and the diversion created draws Yasak's attention but goes wrong, killing Robert, ev for this in next speech.

A. is there evidence is is enraged?
B.please include evidence why the diversion was specifically for Robert to escape.
I believe B more now that I examined the use of y'all quotes. I'm getting that that Koroby was to marry Yasak but she likes Robert. Why she set the fire is still unanswered.

The ev (4937â€“4955) shows that Koroby is very mad at Robert, enough to kill him.

The whole timeline of the story is: Koroby is set to marry Yasak (she doesn't want to). Robert arrives and she falls in love, but Robert rejects her (my quote) and she gets /pissed/ so she starts the fire to get revenge.

Ev for R rejecting her:

B says the fire is for R's escape but that's wrong:
1] K yells while R is running away:
2] The flames /kill/ Robert:
3] "Getting Yasak's attention" is never mentioned in the part about K starting the flame.
The reason for the fire is never explicitly stated, but from its effects we can infer Koroby's intent:

Additionally, A is misconstruing evidence which very easily flows B. Koroby yelling at Robert is because she still loves him and wants him to come back. 

We can rule out the possibility that Koroby wants to hurt Robert. Her vow to kill Robert is a small part of the story. What's more important is her consistent obsession with him:
. Koroby is evidently delusional about their relationship, she loves Robert too much to kill him.
